div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT STEAMERS and RAILWAYS
div.p: xpress service from November 1st, until further notice

‡Sleeping and Dining Cars. From Nov 1st sleeping and dining acrs on Egyptian State Railways are attactched to ordinary trains from Cairo on Mon, Wed and Sat, at 8 p.m. and from Luxor on Tues., Thurs, and Sun, at 5.30 p.m- From 2nd Dec. Luxe trains with sleeping and dining Cars will run on same days leaving Cairo and Luxor at 6.30 p.m.. Early in January these trains will be run daily. Express between Shellal and Halfa carry mails and 1st class passengers only, but 2nd class passengers may be accepted if accomodation is available. Express steamers do not stop at any stations on either up or down journeys between Shellal and Halfa. To insure accommodation official passengers must have warrants stamped "Accommodation Available" by Sudan agent, Cairo, or Civil Secretary, Khartoum. A specially fitted barge with 1st and 2nd class accomodation for native ladies will be attactched to these steamers. There will be a resurateur on these mail steamers.

div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON IN ALGERIA.
div.p: Experiments in the cultivation of cotton in various French Colonies are at present being carried out by "L'Association Cotonnière Co. 'oniale," which was founded in 1903 with a view to encourage cotton cultivation in French Colonies, and ensure an adequate supply of raw material for the cotton industry of France. In Algeria especially the cultivation of cotton is being eagerly prosecuted. In certain districts there possessing climatic conditions similar to bose of Egypt, the experiments point to the likelihood of the successful cultivation of Egyptian cotton. Of the several varieties tried, Yannovitch, Abassi, and Mitafifii have been found the most promising. The Yanovitch variety, which is the most valuable, has been grown with some success in the province of Oran. The Abassi variety, which is the most rapidly maturing, has been successfully cultivated in portions of Mostagenen ; Brown | Egyptian or Mita Fifi cotton has been cultivated here and also in Cbéliff ; this variety is the hardiest of the Egyptian cottons. The American cottons experimented with have been somewhat less productive. "Louisiana" and "Mississippi" grow well, but as the cotton produced is of much lower value than the Egyptian cotton it is likely that greater attention will be directed to the cultivation of the latter varieties.

It is likely that the planters will concentrate their efforts upon the cultivation of varieties of Egyptian cotton, particularly Yablonovitch and Mitafifi, and it is suggested that by hybridisation, types of cotton may be obtained, suited to the climatic conditions of the country. The cultivators have been advised in Algeria to follow the methods adopted in Egypt, where sowing is completed by the end of March and the cotton is harvested by the end of October. In Algeria, the harvesting is completed a little later, generally by about the middle of November.

In 1905, 7,055 lb. of Algerian cotton were sold at Havre, and in 1906, the amount bad increased to 27,240 lb. It is anticipated that the area under cultivation will be greatly extended during the present year, and there is every probability of a large increase in the amount of cotton produced.

Murder in Cairo.

Last evening a Greek named Zakerieh Markati, who resided with his young wife, to whom he had only been married four months, made a furious attack upon her with a razor and decamped. The woman expired almost immediately and though every effort is being made to capture the murderer, no trace of him had, up to the time of writing, been found.

div.head: Ports and Lights
div.p: The Official Enquiry

It is stated that Chitty Bey, Director General of the Ministry of Finance, bas issued his report on the findings of the Court of Enquiry, which has been held to enquire into the corruption and maladministration prevailing in the Parts and Lights Administration. The necessary reforms are outlined and those of the officials of this Administration, whose integrity remains intact, are recommended for promotion.

It is said that Dixon Bey, Director of the Lighthouse Office at Port Said, who has conducted the enquiry in such an impartial manner, is to receive a high Khedivial decoration as a reward for his zeal and activity.

div.head: Pierre Lotis Mummies
div.p: Pierre Loti, the favourite French novelist, has obtained a new acquisition to his weird and wonderful collection of Egyptian mummies. It is, says "PT.O.", that of a young princess, with gilded face, almost as expressive under its mask as it must have been in life. This mummy, which is one of the best in the collection, accentuates in his study the smell that creeps from a winding sheet when a mummy is half murolled." Loti's grievance is that his servants will not move or touch his mummies under any circumstances. "Only think!" he says, "pet one of my servants :world touch this beautiful young woman. They are superstitious about the dead-1 had to carry her upstairs myself. And, would you believe me, as I reached the landing it suddenly flashed through my mind that I was carrying a corpse. I seemed to feel the chill of the dead breast penetrate my own." Noticeable among the other embalmed bodies of dead and gone Egyptian in Loti's study is that of a little three year old girl, who stares down with sight less eyes on her present owner as be sits writing his romances and plays in the still watches of the night

The debates on the estimates Disclosed serious differences in the "blood." The olimax was reached yesterday in the debate on the Army scandals, when the War Minister | replied in an impassioned speech to the spousations of Dr. Paasche, National Liberal Vice President of the Reichstag, of deceiving, the members see the evidence Against Counts:Lynar and Hobenau, who had asked to be put on trial, 1 Amid tremendous excitement the house adJourned on the "bloe" leaders motion to consider the War Minister's Statement. div.head: The Lamert Affair
div.p: Discussion in French Chamber.
(Gazzette's Special Service)

LONDON, Friday. Mr. Benazet, speaking in the French Chamber, complained that Mr. Lambert, ex director of the Khedivial Law School, had sacrificed important interests -- to a question of amour propre. Mr. Pichon, Minister of Foreign Affairs, replying in a friendly speech, expressed his regret at the brusque departure of Mr. Lambert, which precludes any diplomatic attempt to secure the nomination of another Frenchman to the post. Mr Pichon has entered into pourparlers with Sir E Grey on behalf of French educational interests in Egypt and it is trusted that by British goodwill satisfactory assistance will be given to this point

div.head: England in Egypt
div.p: LECTURE BY MR. J.M. ROBERTSON, M.P.
Last week in the Liberal Club, Newcastle, Mr. J.M. Robertson, M.P., lectured on the anb- the object of Egypt. Mr. Alfred Hewson presided.

Mr. Robertson said there should be a moral coherence between the foreign and the home policy of any progressive nation. We first went into Egypt to secure the regular payment of Egyptian debts to European boudbolders. He would never admit that our nation had a right to do such a thing We got gradually entangled more and more in Egypt. However, we were there. It must not be supposed that he was proposing any policy of shuttle He perfectly recognised that once we were in a country of that kind as administrators, to leave suddenly would probably do more harm than any other course they might take. We were in Egypt for finance. Lord Cromer had efficiently co-operated with the great engineers who had been the means of improving still further the wonderful natural resources of Egypt by the really scientific management of the water supply But had they made out a final case when they said they had financed the country well, and added to her material productivity! The percentage of illiterates in the population was very high. There was no ideal of moral progress as compared with the raising of the material facili, ties. Indeed, the, the material prosperity had been the means of degrading and lowering and worsening the people of Egypt. There could be no ultimate defence of rule in India or Egypt until they could say that they were raising the people in the scale of humanity as well as putting more money in their pockets or food in their stomachs. The people were exploited by the bond-holders, who were to say what small fraction should go to education At this moment, it was impossible for any Egyptian to secure scientific instruction in agriculture -- which was the principal industry of the country- in his own language. It was impossible for any Egyptian to secure scientific instruction in any science in his own language. He was told time after time that the present system of education, the teaching of science through English, taught the natives peter Bngglish nor science. They were teaching the unknown through the slightly known. He admitted that wonderful things had been done in the schools, but be pointed out that this did not mean that the boys had thoroughly mastered 'English. We had been going on a wrong tack as regarded education. In every department of the civil service under Lord Cromer the English element had been increasing and the native element was being depressed. We heard a good deal in this country about sedition in Egypt; but we did not hear of the daily insults heaped by newspapers upon the Egyptians by telling them that they were incompetent aud inferior, The administration in Egypt was more auto cratic than that of Russia. Sir Edward Grey, in answer to a question by Dr. Rutherford, said they could not teach the art of government. Then there was no excuse for not beginning at once to give the people some little experience in self-government. They might keep the dividends, keep the hold on the army and on the Suez Canal; but, in the name of justice, of common sense, and of Liberalism, we should set up a progressive policy, and give the people of Egypt a little more of government experience, by which alone could we make a real nation.
A discussion followed the lecture.

div.head: Nile Passenger Service
div.p: Cook's P.S. "Egypt"

For many years past there has been a good tourist service of steamers plying between Cairo and the various points of interest situated in Upper Egypt, but hitherto there has been no approach to the magnificence and comfort which places Messrs Thos. Look and Sons the crew paddle steamer "Egypt" on a plane far above anything which has has been known on the Nile. This steamer, 280 feet long and with w beam of 90 feet, combines all the luxuries of a modern hotel with the comforts of an ocean going liner, and most certainly marks a new epoch in river traffic in Egypt, luxury of detail, and generosity as to space being the chief features of the steamer. Nothing is cramped and nothing is mean, from the native quarters below decks to the spacions drawing room above.

The dining saloon placed almost opposite to the main gangway, is the first thing to command one's attention on stepping on board. It is placed well forward, and its interior is a masterpiece of decorative art The walls are of a white ground with a panelling of delicate green, and the ceiling, lofty enough to give the saloon a feeling of space seldom to be met with on river going stenmens, is of white organised woodwork which harmonizes well with the general tone of the whole, while the farni. ture of famed oak completes the perfection of the idea. A very marked feature of improvement is to be found in the fact that the front age of the saloon is made of plate glass, thus enabling the passenger to retain their view of the country which they are approaching even while at meals, and another departure which has been made from the lines usually followed in the fitting of boats of this class is likely to meet with immediate appreciation, inasmuch as each table is supplied with its own portable electric lamp. The saloon is sufficiently large to seat eighty passengers if necessary, and we will be very much surprised if it is not called upon to contain its full complement, so soon as the boat becomes to be well-known to the passengers to Upper Egypt

At the after end of the saloon there is a passage running across the boat from port to starboard, communicating direct with the galley by a lift, and the passengers will thus receive their food at practically the same heat as when it left the cooking range

Still further aft there are large single cabins, surpassing in their luxury and comfort anything which has hitherto been seen in Egypt, or for that matter in any other river steamer service that we know after. Hackcorbin is more like the well-fitted room in a comfortable dwelling house than a cabin on board a steamer A large wardrobe, a folding table, & marble-topped washstand containing numerous drawers, a comfortable armchair, and a spring bed are the chief articles of furniture which these cabins contain, and in addition to the ordinary plane glass panes, each window is also fitted with a vene. tian shutter and a pane of ground-glass.

At the after-end of the boat a smoking saloon runs nearly the whole beam of the ship, and this again is well fitted with every regard to both taste and comfort. Card and writing tables, Lenticing chairs and lounges are placed about the saloon, but here, as in all other places, there is not the slightest suspicion of crowding, the famitore being in perfect proportion to the space which is allotted to it. A small bar communicates with this room, and there is also a lavatory adjoining. Indeed one need never enter one's cabin for the purpose of washing | ones bands, lavatories being plentiful at every point on each of the deeks.

The goun papion way to the lower deck is of the design usually followed on the P&O. stenders, and it is unquestionably the only river steamer that offers sufficient head room to a tall man to descend without risk of damage to his head. The first cabins on this lower deck | are four berthed and intended for the use of European servants, but further aft there are Thuge double berth cabins ; indeed cabin hard| ly describes them for they are really far more like saloons, and the luxuriance of appointments is fully sustained. Here also nothing has been forgotten, an electric light button is to your hand upon entering the cabin and another is placed at the bed head. The cabins are well lighted and airy. In short they are perfection, and on this |deck there is a dark-room for those who wish to do their own photography, and there are also a certain number of single berth cabins, But the acme of luxury is attained on the top deck where are situated the "cabins de luxe' these suites comprising & sitting room and lavatory in addition to the usual bedroom, and it is hard to imagine a more delightful way of spending ones time in Egypt than to drowse away the hours in such quarters as this on the bosom of the gently flowing Nile. There are tour of these suites, the drawing room oven paying the space immediately forward and the green panelled' walls of the dining saloon are repeated here, though with a slight difference of design more suited to the nature of the room, and a carpet of scarlet gives a wonderful effect of light and contrast which is not unpleasing.

Though the actual beam of the boat is given at 80 feet it must exceed that by a good additional ten feet where amidships large open space has been left free from cabins *This will naturally be the entertainment ground of the steamer also; we noticed "bull" - and other games in the vicinity, and a piano e also proclaimed the nature of the place.

Behind this space there are numerous other a single cabins. To describe them would be only elibe to repeat the praise which has been bestowed upon the others, for as we have already 1 lisaid, nothing that is cramped or mean ha Je been permitted to enter into the scheme of things at all,

At either end of the boat there are Tongues for who those prefer the more silent spots, and the forward and Messrs Cook have taken the wise, s precaution of fitting a plato glass screen, which can be opened or closed at desire. This idea will be greatly appreciated during the colder evenings, when, without it, it would be impossible to remain out on deok at all. The scheme of color with which the boat is decorated is most fascinating in its effect, white grounding with dark green relief being the base of all the decoration, and altogether it may truly be said that the "Egypt" is a floating palace, and we wish her every success on her maiden voyage which is advertised to be made to-tomorrow.

div.head: K.S.C
div.p: Junior Polo Championship

Ten teams have entered for the junior polo championship and the first three matches were played off yesterday A K.S.C. team lined out against Coldstream Guards second team, for the first match at 2.30 p.m., the teams being as follows:--

This match was rather one-sided, the Guards winning by 7 goals to 1. The K.S.C, team had never played together before and were therefore considerably handicapped. They ought, however, to have made a better fight. Mr. Napier made one brilliant ren, scoring their only goal. The Gaards played good polo and kept their places.
Second Match
This was a better game, but the tactios of the Guards were superior, and they won 4 to love. Capt. Kelley had a nasty-looking fall, but his helmet saved him from any injury.
Third Match

This was the best match of the day. The Dragoods started forcing the game and the 60th only just managed to save their goal on several occasions. Just as the bell rang the Dragoons hit through. From the throw in Mr. Bowen dashed away up the ground and scored a beautiful goal, Another was soon afterwards added by Capt. Nixon. Towards the end of the third chukker Capt. Holland unfortunately bad a bad fall and broke his collarbone, bis pony coming down with him. Mr. de Calry took bis place and the game was resumed. The third ohukker the 60th scored goal thus bringing the score to 3 to 2. lo the 4th chukker the 60th were the attacking part and a brilliant ran by Capt. Johnson ending up with a fine shot through the goal brought the score to 3 to 2. During the last 8 or 4 minutes play the 60th made strenuous efforts to equalise but without success. The tournament will be continued to-day.

div.head: Industrial Building and Commercial Company of Egypt Limited
div.p: Au moment où tout le monde discute de la situation de cette société, nous avons eru intéressant de mettre sous les yeux de nos lec teurs quelques explications que nous avons demandées à la Direction. Nous les reproduisons telles quelles sans commentaires de notre part et à simple titre de renseignement, sous la responsabilité de la direction qui nous les a fournies.

L'Industrial, Building and Commercial Com pany of Egypt Limited, appelée communément Karam du nom de son principal promoteur, été formée en février dernier au capital de £ 500.000, en 499,375 actions de £ 1 et 12,500 parte de fondateur de 1 shelling. Mais il n'a été émis que 299.375 actions.

Aux termes mêmes du prospectos d'émission 50.000 actions ont été allouées à M.Karam 25000 a M. Campos et 8000 à M. Scilipoti, er tout 83000 actions revenant aax promoteure pour apports divers à la société.

Il restait 216,375 actions dont le premier versement de 10 shellings a été intégralement encaissé. Quant au deuxième versement, 110,000 actions environ sont restées libérées seulement de 10 shellings, soit un déficit de 55000 livres environ sur lesquelles l'administration était en droit de compter. De ce qui précède il résulte que la société a encaissé environ 163,000 livres.

Sur ce chiffre, toujours pour apports faits à la société, M. Karam a reça £ 40000 au comp tant, M. Campos £ 22000, M. Mattioli £ 5400, M. Soilipoti £ 8700, ce qui avec les £ 8000 de frais généraux de constitution fait un total de £ 84000. Quand on aura ajouté à ce chiffre £25000 pour la construction de la scierie du Caire, le capital immobilisé dans le fonds de roulement et les dépenses faites à la plâtrière du Mariont, on comprendra que le conseil d'administration n'a pas de fortes disponibilités et que s'il vent donner plus d'envergure à ses affaires, il est obligé, comme il est en train de le faire, d'exercer une pression sur les actionnaires en retard du dernier versement.
D'autre part, on conçoit partaitement que oes derniers refusent de complèter leur sold de 10 shellings, quand ils peuvent acheter en place à 5 shellings des titres complètement libérés.
Ceci dit, entrons dans quelques détails su "les affaires de la société.

Où le manque d'argent entrave le plus le intérêts de la Klam, c'est à la platrière de Mariont, qui n'a pu être mise en exploitation faute de capitaux. Il paralt, cependant, d'après un rapport très minutieux du conseil d'administration, que le gisement contient une réserve de plâtre de un million et demi de tonnes. Des techniciens comme MM. Daujat, Tivoli et d'autres qui se sont rendus sur les lieux sont revenus émerveillés tant de la quantité que de la qualité du platre. On a déjà båti la maison de la direction et des maisons ouvrières et on est en train de faire construire une ligne de garage entre la station de Garbagnat et l'em placement de la future usine. La société n'at tepd que d'avoir les fonds nécessaires pour exploiter le précieux gisement.

Bien que ce ne fut pas dans son programme la société acheta de M. Campos environ 100.000 pios carrés de terrains, situés à Ramleh en plasieurs parcelles à Khedivah Palace, Zahrieh, etc. La valeur de ces terrains a été entièrement garantie à la société par M Karam, qui en a endossé toute la responsabi lité. Le conseil a l'intention de revendre ces terrains avec un bénéfice ou d'y élever des villas qu'elle vendra ensuite. De cette façon elle assurerait à son personnel de cons truotion un ouvrage continu et régulier, même dans les intervalles de calme passager.

Les constructions confiées à la société dans la ville d'Alexandrie sont assez nombreuses pour que la direction espère retirer de cette branche des profits appréciables. La Société est restée, entre autres, adjndicataire de la construction des écoles du Gouvernement à Moharrem Bey pour un chiffre qui atteindra probablement 100.000 L.E. Actuellement elle transforme l'ancien local de la Compagnie du Gaz pour en faire le nouveau siège du Comptoir Financier et Commercial.
Pour travaux professionnels de son bureau technique, à savoir projets, devis, expertises etc. la société a déja réalisé de 450 à 500 livres.

La scierie mécanique, achetée de M. Scilipoti au Gabbari est en pleine activité. Le bénéfice ne peut être évalué avant d'avoir procédé à l'inventaire, ce qui demande du temps. Mais l'administration estime d'ores et déjà que cette entreprise donnera de beaux rendements, puisqu'on a été obligé dernièrement de refuser des commandes, le maximum des moyens de production étant atteint. Une autre scierie mécanique plus importante sera bientôt inaugurée au Caire sur un terrain que la société a acquis dans ce but près du pont de Gamrah Les machines sont déjà installées et il manque peu de chose pour mettre l'usine en marche.

Vous le voyez, ajoute notre interlocuteur, toutes les branches que la société a pu mettre en exploitation paraissent appelées au succès. Ce n'est que faute par certains actionnaires en retard d'avoir versé leur solde que l'administration se trouve paralysée au point de vne pécuniaire, en ce qui concerne par exemple la plâtrière du Mariout et le département constructions du Caire qui a do suspendre ses travaux, faute de fonds. Aussi le conseil se proposetil d'appliquer aux actionnaires récaloitrants les règlements des statuts,aux termes desquels leurs actions reviendront à la société qui pourra les considérer comme des actions à réemettre et le montant versé sera acquis à la Société. En aùpposant qu'il y ait 110.000 actions dans o cas, la capital social se trouverait de la sorte réduit à £190,000 contre lesquelles la société dieposerait d'une réserve de £65.000. -A l'article terrains Campos nous avons omis de dire qu'un lot a déjà été vendu à l'Egyptian Hydraulic Stones Co. avec un bénéfice de £1500, ce qui représente 40% de profit sur la superficie vendue.

div.head: Bulletin De la Bourse
div.p: Aujourd'hui d midi

L'annonce que la Banque d'Angleterre ne réduirait pas son taux d'escompte à cause de la demande d'or américaine a eu sa répercussion sur notre place où l'on s'attendait généralement, à cette réduction pour aider à la treprise. Comme bier la corbeille est morne ; on ne fait rien ou à peu près, au point qu'une demande ou une offre insignifiantes suffisent occasionner des oscillations disproportionnées,, fente de contrepartie. En somme, c'est un marché restreint, sans rien de saillant. IL y a eu quelques affaires en Agricole, Delta Light, Daïra et Union Foncière. L'Aboukir, qui était demandée sans vendeurs et vela depuis quelques jours, était offerte aujourd'hui. Les valeurs égyptiennes cotées à Paris sont calmes. Une offre de Urbaine a ramené le cours de ce titre de 3 7/16 à 8 1/4. Bref, l'ensemble est lourd, et sans tendance bien définie. Nous dépendons plus que jamais de l'étranger dont les nouvelles pour le moment sont plutôt défavorables.

L'Agricole progresse de 7 7/8 à 7 29/32, la Deltalight de 9 3/4 à 9 13/16. La Daïra et la National Bank sont soutenues. Quant à l'obligation Crédit Foncier, l'ancienne fléchit de 287 à 286 et la nouvelle de 253 1/2 à 252
Mieux tenue également, la Behera avance de 20 1/4 à 20 3/8, l'Union Foncière de 4 7/16 à 4 1/2 et le Banco di Roma de 103 à 103 1/2.
Les Privilégiées Bière d'Alexandrie tombent, au contraire, de 125 à 120 et la Banque d'Athènes de 118 3/4 à 113

En petites valeurs, la Salt & Soda reprend de 14/3 à 14/9, la Delta Land de 1 9/32 & 1 5/16 et l'Hélouan pousse jusqu'à 3/16, tandis que l'Anglo American Nile rétrograde de 2 1/8 à 2 1/16, l'Aboukir de 28/6 à 28/3, les Ritz de 1/82 à 5/16
La part de fondateur Zariffa recule aussi de 3 1/4 à 3 et le Comptoir Financier passe de 2 17/32 acheteurs à 2 17/32 vendeurs.
Sur le reste de la côte il n'y a pas de changements à signaler. Une enchère de 100 Ritz est annoncé pour lundi prochain.
D'un confrère de Londres :

Je manquerais à mes devoirs de chroniqueur, si je ne vous signalais l'augmentation du capital, de £20,000 à £40,000, de la "Société des Etendards," fondée à l'usage de notre confrère Mustapha Kamel pacha. Il est inutile de vous dire que le pacha s'est dispensé de soumettre à l'approbation des actionnaires le bilan, qui doit révéler, sans aucun doute, un véritable désastre. Mais quoi ! un tel bilan présente-t-il au point de vue financier un intérêt quelconque? Mustafa a préféré en relater les effets moraux. Il a conté à l'assemblée ses exploits et le succès de ses journaux en Europe (sic).
Voilà donc comment, à défaut de dividende, les actionnaires des "Étendards" ont été payés par de belles paroles!

div.head:
Russia and Italy
Russian Squadron's Visit

div.p: (By letter). An event of considerable inter national importance has just been agreed upon, that is a visit of the Russian squadron to Italy for the first time in 5 years. This assumes a special interest considering the strained relations between the two countries after the Tsar abandoned the idea of returning the visit paid to him by King Victor at St. Petersburg Indeed this visit may be the prelude to the Tsar coming to the Eternal City. The squadron is composed of the men of war "Tsarevitch," "Slavo," and "Bogatir," having on board Russian cadets. They will arrive in Genoa on January 3rd, and remain there until the 10th, going after to Spezia. The Admiral, superior officers, and a certain number of cadets will come to Rome, where they will be received by the King, and in whose honour Admiral Mirabello, Minister of the Navy, and M. Muravieff, Russian Ambassador, to whose ability is due the re-establishment of cordial relations between the two countries and the conclusion of a commercial treaty, will give several entertainments.
From Spezia the Russian squadron will go to Biserta, returning from there to Naples in the middle of February and sailing afterwards for Gibraltar.
(Reuter)

The sitting of the Reichstag was suspended yesterday after a stormy scene in consequence of Herr Paasche, the National-Liberal leader, attacking the Government in connection with the army scandals. It is stated that Prince von Buelow has threatened to resign.
The official "Norddeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung" says that it is hopeless to conduct parliamentary business if the coalition parties continue to attack one another or the Government. (Reuter)
At the Reichstag the leaders of all the parties "da blow" declared that they kept their trust in Prince von Buelow. The speakers of the centre and the socialists criticised the "bloc." (Havas)

Reichstag. As the result of a conference with the bloc leaders the latter delivered demonstrative speeches to day promising to support Prince von Buelow, amid the derisive laughter of the centre and the socialists at the sudden reconciliation
A crisis has thus been averted. The committee dealing with the Polish bill has rejected it by 19 votes to 9. (Reuter)
The King and Queen of Spain have disembarked among beauty acclamations. (Havas)
General Lyautey bas organised two columns totalling 8,000 men on the Algerian frontier. (Reuter)
The cotton dispute has been settled. The delegates proceeded in a body to thank Mr. Lloyd George for his assistance. (Reuter)
Mr. J.-D. Campbell, C.M G., Chinese Customs. Mr. Haoc Meyer, the Americen singer king. M. Pena, ex-President of the Argentina. (Reriler)

div.head:
The American Crisis
Rise in Currency Permium

div.p: There has been a renewed rise in the American currency premium. The maintained demand for gold has prevented a reduction in the bank rate. (Router)

The Chamber of Deputies has voted the | budget ot Foreign Affairs. M. Pichon justified the action of France in Morocco regarding its rights, in agreement with the Powers according to the Act of Algeciras, (Havas)

Chamber of Deputies. In the discussion on the foreign estimate M. Pichon rejected the proposal to naturalise Tunisians generally, but said that he would consider the question of naturalising eminent members of the race. M. Pichon, referring to the retirement of M. Lambert in Cairo, declared that Great Britain out of friendship for France would certainly find a means of satisfying her interests. Conversations were now proceeding with Sir E. Grey which he believed he might say would end satisfactorily for all. (Reuter)
The Natal field force lett Gingindlovu for Zululand yesterday.(Reuter)

The garrisons of Bloemfontein, Harrismith, and Standerton are prepared to send mobile columns to Zululand at an hour's notice. It is stated that General Botha has also offered his assistance. The bulk of the troops assembled at Gingindlovu left yesterday. (Renter)
Mouley Hafid's cause is gaining ground. (Havas)

div.head: The Cotton Market
div.p: KEARSLEY AND CUNNINGHAM'S WEEKLY REPORT

LIVERPOOL, November 28. There has been slightly more business pat through this week, but the demand is freely met 'and quotations of fair to Fully Good Fair Brown are reduced to lb. and I'ppers plb. The finer qualities are unchanged.

In Futures only a moderate business has been done, and the following are the latest values : Nov. 9.58 Feb. 9.47 May 9.45 Ang. 9.45 Dec. 9.49 Mar. 9.46 June 9.45 Sept. 9.44 Jan. 9.48 Apr. 9.45 July 9.45 Oct. 9.42 Nov. '08. 9.39

American Futures. The labor dispute in the Lancashire Spinning Trade although not settled yet looks less dark since the President of the Board of Trade has offered his services as a mediator, and bopes are now entertained that a reconciliation may be arrived at. This, and the better feeling in financial circles have given more confidence, and prices are 17@231 points higher than last week.

There is nothing very new in the way of Crop News. Estimates keep coming in, and vary according to the source they come from. There appears to be a good fight going on in New York between two powerful syndicates, and so long as this manipulation continues it is impossible to form an opinion as to the course of the Market, and it makes the position of the legitimate operator dangerous. It is reported that the New York "Bulls" have been shipping actual cotton to Liverpool rather freely.

div.head: Anglo-Belgian Co. of Egypt
div.p: Results Considered Satisfactory in view of the Crisis

The second ordinary general meeting of the Anglo-Belgian Company of Egypt, Limited, was held on the 28th Nov.at the Cannon-street Hotel, under the presidency of Baron George de Renter (the chairman of the company.
The Secretary (Mr. G.T. Broadbridge, P|F.C.I.S.) having read the notice calling the meeting and the auditors' report.

The Chairman, in the course of an exhaustive speech, said: Although you will have seen from the report that there is no question of paying a dividend at the present moment nevertheless your directors have considered it advisable to call a meeting now, instead of waiting to close the books at the end of the year, when we should probably have been able to put a more attractive report and profit and loss account before you. This company was incorporated, as you are aware, on March 3, 1906, as an English company, the nominal capital being £1,000,000 in 200,000 shares of £5 each. The prospectus of the company, offering 100,000 of these shares for subscription, was dated March 6, 1906. The total number of shares allotted to date is 70,000, which has produced, £346,680 108. working capital. As you know, the company has acquired a controlling interest in the Fayoum Light Railways Company (an Egyptian company), which railway is situated in the Payoum Province, near Cairo, and is about 168 kilomètres equal to about 108 English miles in length. As you may remember, this concession gives the monopoly ot light railways in the Fayoum Province-one of the most fertile in Egypt, and one in which a great development is taking place. The controlling interest which we possess consists of holding in the railway company sufficient of its shares and obligations to be able to control its business management (about four-fifths of the whole), and, apart altogether from possessing the control of the railway company's capital, we also have the control on the board of that company. As your chairman, I also hold the office of president of the railway company, and another of your directors (Monsieur Freson) is the vice-president, whilst still another (Monsieur Florent Lambert) is also on the board of the railway. I may mention that we have on the railway board English and Belgian gentlemen who have great experience and success in the management of light railways, whose expert advice is therefore of inestimable value.

As you were informed in the prospects, and again at our statutory meeting of last year, the condition of the railways company when we took it over left a great deal to be desired ; in fact, nothing could be more severe than the strictures passed upon the old administration of that company by Lord Cromer, in his report of last year. The carrying out of the programme of reform necessarily required a considerable amount of time and the expenditure of a considerable sum of money. You will be pleased to know that when I and one of your directors (Monsieur Freson) went to Egypt last winter, to negotiate with the Government regarding modifications in the concession which we had requested, we were able to satisfy the Government that their requirements with regard to the conduct of the company had been given effect to, with the result that the modifications asked for by us have now been granted. I should also tell you that we have obtained the advantage of postponing the date at which the Government has the right to purchase the line ----some three years. We have made great strides towards putting the undertaking upon a thoroughly good and effective basis, which will mean increased profits in the future. At the general meeting of the railways company held in Cairo, on February 25 of this year, we bad the satisfaction of reporting that not only had we expended large sums in carrying out the major part of our programme, but that, for the first time in the annals of the company, interest had been paid in cash, and a resolution? was passed at that meeting authorising the directors to pay during the current year the coupon on the debentures which still remained in arrears.

Having given figures as to the actual work ing of the railway, showing increased traffic receipts and a reduction of the ratio of the working expenses, the Chairman said that be had no hesitation in saying that, in his opinion and that of the management of the railway company, they would not regret the acquisition of that company's control. Proceeding, be said : I do not think I can do better, by way of illustrating to you the progress that has been made since we took over the control, than quote to you from the report made by Lord Cromer in the Blue-Book issued before his retirement, in which he reports to the Foreign Office here as follows: "There are now 1,145 kilomètres of agricultural railways open in Egypt. All the three companies concerned seem to be doing well. Notably, there has been a great improvement in the management of the Fayoum lines, upon whose administration I have animadverted in previous reports. European agency has been introduced into the management, with the result that in 1906 the working expenses were L.E. 4,000 less and the net earning L.E. 6,000 more than in 1906." I may remark that we feel somewhat proud to have had such a commendation passed upon our management from such a high authority. Having such a stake in the Fayoum Railway Company, it was, of course, to our manifest interest to push that concern ahead as much as ever we could, and to do that it was necessary to provide it with the means of adding to its rolling stock, locomotives, &c., and we therefore entered into a contract with the railway company to make them a loan of £82,000, with interest at the rate of 6 percent per annum and this loan will be redeemed by the railway company by the creation of a sinking fund We are of opinion that this loan is an excellent investment, not merely from the rate o interest earned (and which is regularly paid but principally from the fact that this financing is enabling the railway company to augment its rolling stock and locomotives, and general overhaul its permanent way and other important matters which, to a progressing con cern, as a railway ought to be, is an important factor. In addition to this loan which we have made to the railway company, it i further indebted to us in the sum of £28,51188 being a debt taken over by this company included in the purchase price paid for the shares and obligations of the railway company Particulars as to our land and properties are count you will see set forth in the balance sheet. One purchase of land which we have made consists of 10,612 square metres a Shoubrah. We have had this land divider into 22 plots, and recently, in the midst of the most acute stage of the financial crisis in Egypt, we disposed of one of these plots at al exceedingly good profit. It we dispose of the other plots on this estate with a profit of one half that made on the plot already sold, thi whole transaction would result in a profit of between £12,000 and. £15,000 ; but we had originally intended to erect villas upon thi plots, and if the condition of Egyptian affair permits our adhering to this policy, the profit to the company should be on a far larger scale

With regard to the profit and loss account you will observe that there is shown a net profit of £2,311 16s. 8d., and I cannot help thinking that this is an exceedingly satisfactory position to arrive at when, as I have stated earlier in my remarks, all our properties have been taken an oost, and when it is borne in mind that during the last few months of the winter season-ati time when we expected to release at least some of our purchases-Egyptian affairs passed through a most acute financial crisis. You will have noticed from the directors' report that the sum of £7,044 49. 4d., interest on the company's Fayoum obligations for the year 1904-5, being the date previous to which the company acquired such obligations, has beer written off preliminary expenses, instead of being taken into profit and loss. In adopting this course the directors were supported by the company's legal advisers. I should observe that the accrued interest on the Fayoum debentures coupons for 1907 does not appear in the accounts, and therefore our position is really better than it appears from the same by some £2,035. To refer once more to our land acquisitions, our representatives in Egypt had the same valued by two local firms of experts, with the object of ascertaining from their value. tion whether what we had acquired had depression. coated or appreciated. One valuation showed a depreciation of £9,800—or only of about 5 per cent.-while the other showed an appreciation of £7,580. To set your minds at rest on this point, and to prove to you that we have sustained no loss in our investments in this direction. I would like to tell you that in our opinion the valuations were pessimistic, and we are confirmed in this opinion by the fact that since the valuation in question, or, rather, whilst the valuation was actually taking place, we sold a portion of one of our properties at nearly double the price put upon it in the said valuation. And again, two months ago we received an offer for the exchange of a portion of another of our properties against some agricultural land upon a basis that would pay the price of the property in question 75 per cent. higher than that put upon it in the valuation. I now beg to move : "That the report and accounts as at July 31, 1907, be adopted."

Mr. G. Carlier seconded the motion, which was carried unanimously. Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt were reappointed auditors, and a vote of thanks to the chairman, moved by Mr. Bird and seconded by Sir Thomas Pile, concluded the proceedings,

div.head: British Slaves in Turkey
div.p: A Quaint Request

A bequest by Mr. Thomas Betton, a wealthy ironmonger who died in 1724, of one-half the residue of his estate to the Ironmongers' Company, to be devoted to "the redemption of British slaves in Turkey or Barbary," was the subject of considerable discussion before Mr. Justice Swinfen Fady in the Chancery Division last Thursday. For over a hundred years after the death of the testator large sums were employed in carrying out his wishes, the last payment being made in 1825. The income being then much more than sufficient for the object in view, a scheme for the management of the fund was formulated in Chancery. The scheme to which the present litigation applied was established by the Charity Commissioners, who, under the powers conferred upon them by the Board of Education Act, 1899, decided that the money should be applied for educational purposes. The Ironmongers' Company, what are the trustees of the fund, appealed against the scheme on the ground that its effect was to devote permanently to educational purposes trust money bequeathed for the redemption of British slaves. The full terms of the bequest were: "I give and bequeath the rest and residue of my estate wheresoever and whatsoever to the Worshipful Company or Corporation of Ironmongers of the City of London and their successors, making them my executors upon this special trust and confidence in them reposed, that is to say that they do with all convenient speed that may be after my decease place my estate out at interest upon good securities, positively forbidding them to diminish the capital sum by giving away any part thereof, or that the interest and profit arising be applied to any other use or uses than hereinafter mentioned and directed, namely, that they do pay one full half portion of the said interest and profit of my whole estate yearly and for every year for ever unto the redemption of British slaves in Turkey or Barbary, one full tourth-part of the said interest and profit yearly, and every year for ever unto charity schools in the City and suburbs of London where the education is according to the Church of England, in which number that in this parish is to be included, and not giving any one above £20 per year, and in consideration of the said Ironmongers' Company's care and pains in the execution of this my will the other one-fourth part of the said interest and profit yearly and for every year for ever to the uses following, namely, £10 a year to such minister of the Church of England as they shall from time to time enjoin in their hospital for performing the Divine service and other duties belonging to the Holy Order, and the remains unto necessitated decayed freemen of the said Company, their wives, and children not exceeding £10 a year to any family."

Mr. Justice Swinfen Bady asked if there was now no British subject held in captivity under Moslem rule. Mr. Eve, K.C. - At the present moment there may be a quarter where the fund would be extremely acceptable, and might be applied as the testator contemplated. | Mr. Justice Swinfen Eady held that the scheme of the Charity Commissioners did not in any way restrict or alter the object of the charity, or prevent the fund at some future time being applied under some different or altered scheme to other than educational purposes if circumstances should arise rendering that course expedient.

With reference to Notice to Mariners of September 28th 1907, regarding the new beacon to be placed at the outer entrance to the Great Pass, notice is hereby given that the beacon is now in poition.
A fixed white light will be placed on it temporarily, and the gas buoy removed
When the Great Pass is opened to traffic, this fixed light will be changed to a white occulting light with a period of 5 seconds (approximately). The light will be unwatched.
Position of Beacon
Bearings are magnetic and taken from the beacon
Name- Great Pass Gas Beacon
Colour-Chocolate
Depth of water alongside 24 to 26 feet
Height of focal plane above H. W. -47 feet. General description- Open Iron work.
Miles seen in clear weather-5.
New Leading Light for Great Pass
A front leading light has been erected for the Great Pass on the Mex shore and lights will be exhibited from it when the Pass is opened to traffic.
There will be three fixed lights placed vertically shown from the tower, the upper and lower being red, and the centre one white.
Bearings are magnetic and goven from the lighthouse
Name Great Pass Low Light
General Description-Masonry, circular with red and white bands, and the lantern surmounted by a spike and ball, dwelling with red roofs, adjacent.
Height of tower-64 feet
Top of tower to H.W. 72 feet
Height of Upper light above H.W. 58 feet
Centre light above H.W. 43 feet
Lower light above H.W. 28 feet
Miles seen in clear weather-5
The Great Pass

The dredging of the Great Pass has been completed, and it is expected that it will be opened to traffic about the end of the present year after the survey is completed. 1 The pass is 600 feet wide, and will have a least depth of 35 feet throughout its length.
LEADING MARKS etc.
At the outer entrance on the Southern side is placed the Gas beacon, before mentioned.

Just off the Southern side, on a rock with about 8 feet of water on it, which lies to the Northward of the Hydrographer shoal, and within about 30 yards from the sideline of the Pass, will be placed an open iron work beacon.
Off the Northern side, on the South end of the North shoal, will be placed a similar beacon.
Full description of these beacons will be given when they are in position.

On the shore, is the lighthouse before mentioned, and there will also be iron beacons to mark the sides of the Pass, in the same manner as the Boghaz Pass. Full description of these beacons will be given when they are erected.

To enter the Pass from seaward, keep the Great Pass Low Lighthouse in line with the Mex High Lighthouse, by day, and the five lights in line vertically, by night, on a bearing S. 67° E (true) which will lead through in noi less than 35 feet of water.

When the Great Pass is opened the Boghaz Pass will be closed for night traffic, and the two red lights in Mex Low Lighthouse will not be exhibited, until further notice, to date from the commencement of the use of the Great Pass.
The exact true bearing of the centre line of the Great Pass, through the centres of Mex High Lighthouse, and Great Pass Low Lighthouse is:
NS 67 06 47 WE
Dredging Lights
The use of these lights has been discontinued, and the poles on which they were placed will shortly be removed.
Mex High & Low Lights
The lights in the mEx High and Low Lighthouses have been changed from C.D 6th Order to C.D. 4th Order.
Herbert J. Gedge
For Director General
31460-2-2 Alexandria, November 18th 1907

div.head: Egyptian Constructions Ltd.
div.p: NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN THAT AN EXTRAORDINARY GENERAL MEETING of the above named Company will be held at the Grand Continental Hotel Cairo on Saturday the 21st day of December 1907 at four o'clock in the afternoon, at which the following Resolutions will be submitted,
1. That the Capital of the Company consisting of £200,000 divided into 200,000 Shares of £1 each be reduced to £132,750 divided into 265,500 Shares of ten shillings each as follows :
a) by cancelling 12,500 Shares numbered 5,001 to 7,500 and 100,001 to 110,000 each fully paid.
b) by reducing each of the 109,500 Shares numbered 1 to 5,000 750 to 100,000-110,001 to 122,000 each fully paid, from £1 to ten shillings.

2. That each of the 78,000 Shares of £1 each remaining unissued shall be divided into two shares of ten shillings each. Should the above resolutions be duly passed by the requisite majority of the same will be duly submitted for confirmation as Special Resolutions to a subsequent General Meeting of the Company which will be held at the same time and place on Wednesday the 8th day of January 1908.
At the same Meeting a Resolution will be submitted by the Directors authorizing them to sell or otherwise dispose of certain portions of the businesses acquired by the Company.
Holders of bearer warrants must deposit thein at the ANGLO EGYPTIAN BANK either at Cairo or Alexandria at least 48 hours before the Meeting.

Shareholders who have not taken up their bearer warrants may do so without further formality. Proxies must be left at the Company's Offices at 18 Chareh Abdeen, Cairo, at least 48 hours before the Meeting and should be in proper form.
By order of the Board.
JACKSON H. BROOKS. 31461-32
Secretary in Egypt.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette. "
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the "Egyptian Gazette."

Conformément aux avis insérés dans les journaux locaux et aux conditions spéciales réglant le tirage des titres, il a été procédé, le 2 Décembre 1907, à 5h. 1/2 p.m., au Palais Municipal, en séance publique, an le tirage de 21 titres de l'Emprunt Municipal, da ler janvier 1902, et ce, en vue de leur amortissement.
Sont sortis au tirage, les numéros suivants : lo. No. 269 des titres de L.E. 500.
